column4: He doesn't need to run update-grub and removing the "quiet" doesn't help
if he only removed quiet from the kopt=, commented line, then yes, he does need to run update-grub
I asked if he wanted to see what happens when his system's booting, apparantly not, so leave splash in.  removing quiet shows what grub does before it starts booting the kernel though
No, he doesn't. I have done that on several boxes and never need to run update-grub.
you really do..
for a test, add something to the commented line, examine the rest of the file.  then run update-grub and examine the rest of the file
look, I just ran a test to be absolutely sure, and you absolutely, definitely do need to run update-grub
Please stop, I know what I'm doing.
as do I
Pleaced you on my ignore list.
ignore someone who tells you the correct way to do it, fine..
I'd answer, but you already ignored me for pointing out you need to run 'update-grub'...
That comment was completely unnecessary and quite childish
Go change your diaper
superfluous indeed, however I'm certain I was right..
So you know how to fix it?

it's most likely caused by the preview engine (have you been browing paths with videos?), there's no permanent fix but 'killall nautilus' will respawn nautilus, and it won't choke on the same files again
I don't work with videos at all. But, will keep it in mind.
np's, if you want more detail, you can 'strace' the process
Also, one of the things I do in my initial tweaks is turn all previews off.
strace -p *nautilus process id*, that'll tell you which calls it's racing on
may not immediately help, but it's a lot more useful information :)
Ahh, I'll add that to my notes. Thank you, sir :)
